title: First Episode Psychosis — Schizophrenia
chief_complaint: Talking to himself, suspicious behavior, and social withdrawal for 6 months
presentation: A 22-year-old engineering student is brought by his parents with gradual onset of talking/laughing to himself, suspicion that neighbors are plotting against him, hearing voices commenting on his actions, progressive social withdrawal, and declining academic performance over 6 months. He has poor insight and refuses to acknowledge any illness.
history: Insidious onset over 6 months. Auditory hallucinations: Hears 2-3 voices discussing him (third-person commentary type). Persecutory delusions: Believes neighbors have installed cameras, food is being poisoned. Thought broadcasting: Believes others can read his thoughts. Social withdrawal: Stopped attending college, stays in room. Self-care deterioration: Not bathing, disheveled. Sleep disturbance. No substance use. No family history of psychiatric illness. No head injury. No seizures. Premorbid personality: Introverted but functionally normal.
physical_exam: Disheveled appearance, poor hygiene. Eye contact: Avoidant. Affect: Flat, incongruent (laughs inappropriately). Speech: Tangential, occasional loosening of associations. Hallucinations: Appears to respond to internal stimuli. Delusions: Fixed, systematized persecutory delusions. Insight: Absent. Judgment: Impaired. No focal neurological deficit. No signs of substance abuse.
investigations: Diagnosis is clinical (ICD-11/DSM-5 criteria). CBC, RFT, LFT, TFT: Normal (baseline before starting antipsychotics). Blood glucose, lipid profile: Normal (baseline — antipsychotics cause metabolic syndrome). Urine drug screen: Negative. MRI brain: Normal (rules out organic causes in first episode). EEG: Normal. HIV, VDRL: Negative.
diagnosis: Schizophrenia — first episode psychosis (paranoid type, ICD-11: >1 month of symptoms with Schneiderian first-rank symptoms)
differentials: Organic psychosis (temporal lobe epilepsy, brain tumor)
learning_points: Schneiderian first-rank symptoms: Auditory hallucinations (commentary/discussing), thought insertion/withdrawal/broadcasting, delusions of control — suggestive but not pathognomonic of schizophrenia
Diagnosis requires >1 month of symptoms (ICD-11) with significant functional impairment
First episode: MRI brain mandatory to rule out organic causes before labeling as schizophrenia
Treatment: Second-generation antipsychotics (risperidone 2-6 mg, olanzapine 10-20 mg) are first-line
Duration of untreated psychosis (DUP) predicts outcome — shorter DUP = better prognosis
Metabolic monitoring: Weight, glucose, lipids at baseline and regularly (olanzapine worst for weight gain)
india_context: Schizophrenia prevalence in India is 3-4 per 1000. Stigma is the biggest barrier to treatment — families hide illness, consult traditional healers first. Average DUP in India is 1-2 years. Mental Healthcare Act 2017 guarantees right to mental healthcare. DMHP (District Mental Health Programme) provides psychiatric care at district level. Generic antipsychotics are affordable.

title: Major Depressive Disorder with Suicidal Ideation
chief_complaint: Persistent sadness, loss of interest, and thoughts of ending life for 3 months
presentation: A 35-year-old married schoolteacher presents with persistent low mood, loss of interest in all activities (anhedonia), fatigue, insomnia, poor concentration, guilt, appetite loss with 6 kg weight loss, and active suicidal ideation with a plan (has been collecting medications) for 3 months. She recently went through a difficult divorce process.
history: Depressed mood: Persistent, worse in mornings (diurnal variation). Anhedonia: Lost interest in teaching, music, socializing. Sleep: Early morning awakening (4 AM, unable to go back to sleep — typical). Appetite: Markedly decreased, lost 6 kg. Fatigue: Cannot complete daily tasks. Concentration: Making errors at work. Guilt: Excessive, inappropriate guilt about divorce. Suicidal ideation: Active, with plan (has collected excess medications). Previous episode of depression 5 years ago (treated with escitalopram, remitted). Divorce proceedings ongoing (psychosocial stressor). No substance use. No psychotic symptoms.
physical_exam: Appearance: Neatly dressed but tearful, poor eye contact, psychomotor retardation (slow movements, long pauses before answering). Speech: Low volume, monotonous. Mood: 'I feel like a burden, there's no point.' Affect: Depressed, congruent, restricted range. Thought content: Ideas of worthlessness, hopelessness, active suicidal ideation WITH PLAN. No hallucinations. Insight: Partial. Cognition: Intact but subjective poor concentration.
investigations: PHQ-9 score: 24 (severe depression). Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale: Active suicidal ideation with plan (HIGH RISK). TSH: Normal (rule out hypothyroidism). Hb: Normal (rule out anemia). Vitamin B12: Normal. Blood glucose: Normal. No investigations specific to depression — diagnosis is clinical.
diagnosis: Major depressive disorder — recurrent, severe, with active suicidal ideation and plan (high-risk)
learning_points: DSM-5: ≥5 of 9 symptoms for ≥2 weeks (SIGECAPS: Sleep, Interest, Guilt, Energy, Concentration, Appetite, Psychomotor, Suicidality) + depressed mood
ALWAYS assess suicide risk: Ideation → Plan → Intent → Access to means → Protective factors
Active suicidal ideation with plan = psychiatric emergency — hospitalization indicated
Treatment severe depression: SSRI (escitalopram/sertraline) + psychotherapy (CBT). ECT for treatment-resistant or immediate suicidal risk
ECT is highly effective and fast-acting — consider early in severe depression with active suicidality
SSRI takes 2-4 weeks for effect — bridge with benzodiazepine for anxiety/insomnia if needed, but not long-term
india_context: Depression affects 5-10% of Indian population. India accounts for 36% of global suicides. National Suicide Prevention Strategy launched in 2022. KIRAN helpline (1800-599-0019) provides 24/7 free mental health support. Stigma prevents help-seeking — only 10-20% of depressed individuals seek treatment. Generic SSRIs (escitalopram, sertraline) cost Rs 2-5/day.

title: Bipolar Disorder — Acute Manic Episode
chief_complaint: Decreased sleep, excessive talking, grandiosity, and reckless spending for 2 weeks
presentation: A 28-year-old software engineer is brought by his wife with 2 weeks of decreased need for sleep (sleeping 2 hours yet feeling energetic), excessive talking (pressured speech), grandiose plans (claims he will become PM, has filed patents worth billions), reckless spending (bought a luxury car on EMI), hypersexuality, and irritability when challenged. He had a depressive episode 2 years ago.
history: Onset 2 weeks ago: Initially seemed 'extra happy' and productive. Then: Decreased need for sleep (2-3 hours), felt refreshed. Pressured speech: Talks non-stop, jumps between topics. Grandiosity: Claims divine connection, plans to run for PM. Reckless behavior: Bought luxury car (Rs 35 lakhs on credit), invested savings in dubious scheme. Hypersexuality: Inappropriate advances. Irritable when confronted. Previous depressive episode 2 years ago (treated with sertraline — may have triggered hypomanic switch). Family history: Father had 'mood swings' (likely bipolar). No substance use.
physical_exam: Dressed flamboyantly (bright colors, excessive jewelry). Psychomotor agitation — cannot sit still. Speech: Pressured, loud, rapid, flight of ideas. Mood: 'I feel fantastic, on top of the world!' Affect: Euphoric, labile (suddenly becomes irritable when questioned). Thought content: Grandiose delusions. No hallucinations. Insight: Absent ('I am fine, everyone else is jealous'). Judgment: Severely impaired.
investigations: Clinical diagnosis — based on DSM-5/ICD-11 criteria. Young Mania Rating Scale (YMRS): 38 (severe mania, >20 indicates mania). TSH: Normal (hyperthyroidism can mimic mania). Urine drug screen: Negative (stimulants, cannabis can cause mania-like state). CBC, RFT, LFT: Normal (baseline before mood stabilizers). Blood glucose: Normal. ECG: Normal (baseline before lithium). Serum calcium: Normal (hyperparathyroidism can cause mood symptoms).
diagnosis: Bipolar I disorder — acute manic episode with psychotic features (grandiose delusions), previous depressive episode
learning_points: Mania diagnostic criteria (DIG FAST): Distractibility, Insomnia (decreased need for sleep), Grandiosity, Flight of ideas, Activity increase, Speech (pressured), Thoughtlessness (reckless behavior) — ≥3 (or 4 if only irritable mood) for ≥1 week
ONE manic episode = Bipolar I (even without depressive episodes). Hypomania + depression = Bipolar II
Antidepressants can trigger mania in bipolar patients — always screen for bipolar before starting antidepressants
Acute mania treatment: Lithium OR valproate + antipsychotic (olanzapine/quetiapine) for behavioral control
Lithium monitoring: Therapeutic level 0.6-1.0 mEq/L (acute: up to 1.2). Check levels 5 days after initiation
Lithium side effects: Tremor, polyuria (NDI), hypothyroidism, weight gain. Teratogenic (Ebstein anomaly)
india_context: Bipolar disorder prevalence in India is 0.5-1.5%. Often misdiagnosed as schizophrenia or depression initially. Lithium is cheap (Rs 1-2/day) and widely available — remains first-line in India. Valproate is alternative but TERATOGENIC — avoid in women of childbearing age. IPS recommends lithium monitoring every 3-6 months. Many patients stop medication when feeling well (during euthymia).

title: Alcohol Dependence Syndrome with Delirium Tremens
chief_complaint: Confusion, tremors, seeing insects on walls, and agitation after stopping alcohol
presentation: A 45-year-old autorickshaw driver with 20 years of heavy daily alcohol use presents 72 hours after his last drink with severe confusion, visual hallucinations (seeing insects crawling on walls), coarse tremors, profuse sweating, tachycardia, and a seizure in the emergency department. He stopped drinking 3 days ago because of hospitalization for a leg fracture.
history: Alcohol use: 20 years, daily 750 mL arrack/brandy (>60 units/week). Last drink 72 hours ago (stopped due to hospital admission for leg fracture). CAGE: 4/4 (positive for dependence). Timeline: 12 hours: Tremors, anxiety, nausea. 24 hours: Insomnia, tachycardia, sweating. 48 hours: Auditory/visual hallucinations. 72 hours: Confusion, disorientation, agitation, seizure. Previous withdrawal episodes: 2 episodes with tremors and hallucinations (kindling effect). Liver disease symptoms: Abdominal distension, jaundice.
physical_exam: Agitated, disoriented (time, place, person — delirium). Coarse tremors of hands. Profuse diaphoresis. Visual hallucinations: Picking at bedsheets (Lilliputian hallucinations), looking at walls frightened. Tachycardic, hypertensive, febrile. Icterus. Palmar erythema, spider nevi (chronic liver disease). Parotid enlargement. Tender hepatomegaly. Ascites. Asterixis. CIWA-Ar score: 28 (severe withdrawal, >20 = severe).
investigations: CIWA-Ar score: 28 (Clinical Institute Withdrawal Assessment). CBC: Macrocytic anemia (MCV 105), thrombocytopenia (80,000). LFT: AST 180, ALT 90 (AST:ALT ratio >2 — alcoholic liver disease), GGT 350 (markedly elevated). Bilirubin: 4.5. Albumin: 2.5. PT/INR: 1.8 (coagulopathy). RBS: 60 (hypoglycemia). Magnesium: 1.2 (low). Phosphate: Low. Thiamine level: Low. ABG: Metabolic alkalosis (vomiting). USG abdomen: Hepatomegaly, fatty liver, ascites. CT brain: No SDH or SOL.
diagnosis: Delirium tremens (severe alcohol withdrawal) in a patient with alcohol dependence syndrome and alcoholic liver disease
learning_points: Delirium tremens: Onset 48-96 hours after last drink. Confusion + autonomic hyperactivity + visual hallucinations + seizures
CIWA-Ar protocol for withdrawal management: >20 = severe, treat aggressively with benzodiazepines
Benzodiazepines are the treatment of choice: Diazepam loading (10-20mg IV q1-2h) OR lorazepam (if liver failure)
Give IV thiamine (500mg TDS x 3 days) BEFORE glucose — glucose without thiamine precipitates Wernicke encephalopathy
Wernicke triad: Ophthalmoplegia + Ataxia + Confusion — often incomplete. Treat empirically if suspected
DT mortality is 5-15% without treatment, <1% with proper benzodiazepine and ICU management
india_context: Kerala has the highest per-capita alcohol consumption in India. Alcohol dependence affects 5-10% of adult males nationally. Arrack and toddy are commonly consumed. NIMHANS Bengaluru is a leading center for addiction treatment. De-addiction centers under DMHP are available in all districts. National Drug De-addiction Programme provides free treatment.

title: Conversion Disorder — Functional Neurological Symptom Disorder
chief_complaint: Sudden inability to move legs after an argument at home
presentation: An 18-year-old girl is brought to the emergency with sudden onset inability to move both legs since this morning, following a heated argument with her father about her wanting to continue education vs an arranged marriage. She appears surprisingly calm despite the 'paralysis' (la belle indifference). Neurological examination shows inconsistencies. She had a similar episode 1 year ago that resolved spontaneously.
history: Sudden onset bilateral leg weakness/paralysis this morning after an argument about arranged marriage (identifiable psychosocial stressor). Appears unable to move legs voluntarily. No pain. No sensory loss. No bladder/bowel involvement. La belle indifference: Appears indifferent to her dramatic symptom. Previous similar episode: 1 year ago (resolved in 3 days after family conflict resolved). No headache, no LOC, no seizures. No trauma. Academic stress ongoing.
physical_exam: Calm, cooperative, la belle indifference. Motor: Bilateral leg paralysis claimed (grade 0/5 on voluntary testing). BUT: Hoover sign POSITIVE (involuntary extension of 'paralyzed' leg when flexing the opposite hip against resistance — inconsistency). Hip flexion on bed shows normal power when attention diverted. Deep tendon reflexes: NORMAL (should be abnormal in UMN or LMN lesion). Plantars: Flexor bilaterally (normal — should be extensor in UMN). Sensation: Non-dermatomal, stocking distribution loss (anatomically inconsistent). No muscle wasting. No fasciculations.
investigations: MRI spine: Normal. MRI brain: Normal. NCV/EMG: Normal (no neuropathy or radiculopathy). CBC, TFT, calcium: Normal. These are done to rule out organic causes — diagnosis is clinical based on positive signs of functional disorder, NOT just negative investigations.
diagnosis: Conversion disorder (Functional Neurological Symptom Disorder — DSM-5) with functional paralysis
learning_points: Conversion disorder diagnosis requires POSITIVE signs of functional disorder (Hoover sign, inconsistencies), NOT just absence of organic disease
Hoover sign: Involuntary hip extension when flexing the other hip — positive = functional weakness
La belle indifference: Lack of concern about severe symptoms — suggestive but NOT reliable alone
DSM-5 removed the requirement for identifiable stressor — but stressors are commonly found
Treatment: Explanation (name the condition, validate symptoms are real but not from structural damage), physiotherapy, CBT
Conversion is NOT malingering (unconscious mechanism) — patients genuinely experience symptoms
india_context: Conversion disorder is common in India, especially in young women facing psychosocial stressors (marriage, family conflicts, academic pressure). Often first seen in emergency/neurology departments. Frequently mismanaged — dramatic treatments (cold water splashing, aversive techniques) are still used and are harmful. IPS recommends empathetic, non-confrontational approach with physiotherapy and psychotherapy.

title: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)
chief_complaint: Excessive handwashing and intrusive thoughts about contamination for 2 years
presentation: A 25-year-old IT professional presents with 2 years of intrusive, distressing thoughts about contamination (obsessions) leading to repetitive handwashing for 3-4 hours daily (compulsions). He recognizes the behavior is excessive (good insight) but cannot control it. He has developed cracked, bleeding skin on his hands. His work performance has suffered and he is at risk of losing his job.
history: Onset 2 years ago: Intrusive thought that doorknobs, surfaces are contaminated with germs. Washes hands repeatedly (20-30 times/day, 3-4 hours total). Also showers 2-3 times daily for 1 hour each. Avoids touching anything in office. Changed clothes immediately upon returning home. Insight: Present ('I know it's irrational but I can't stop'). Resistance: Tries to resist but overwhelming anxiety forces compliance. Interference: Late to work, missing deadlines. Y-BOCS score: 28 (severe). No depressive symptoms currently. No substance use. Family history: Mother has 'checking rituals' (undiagnosed OCD).
physical_exam: Hands: Severe contact dermatitis — cracked, excoriated, bleeding skin from excessive washing. Appears anxious. Otherwise normal physical examination. Mental status: Anxious mood. Obsessions described clearly. Insight present. No psychotic symptoms. No suicidal ideation.
investigations: Y-BOCS (Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale): 28/40 (severe; >16 = clinically significant). Diagnosis is clinical. TSH: Normal. CBC: Normal. No specific lab tests for OCD. Brain imaging: Not routinely needed (but if done: may show increased activity in caudate nucleus and orbitofrontal cortex on fMRI).
diagnosis: Obsessive-compulsive disorder — contamination obsessions with washing compulsions, severe (Y-BOCS 28)
differentials: Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder (OCPD — no insight issues)
learning_points: Obsessions: Intrusive, unwanted, distressing thoughts. Compulsions: Repetitive behaviors to reduce anxiety from obsessions
Common themes: Contamination/washing, doubt/checking, symmetry/ordering, forbidden thoughts
OCD has INSIGHT (ego-dystonic) — patient knows behavior is irrational. OCPD has NO insight (ego-syntonic)
First-line treatment: SSRI (fluoxetine 40-80mg or fluvoxamine — higher doses needed than for depression) + ERP (Exposure and Response Prevention therapy)
ERP is THE most effective psychotherapy — gradual exposure to feared stimulus while preventing compulsive response
If SSRI fails: Clomipramine (most effective anti-obsessional but more side effects) or augment with low-dose antipsychotic
india_context: OCD prevalence in India is 2-3%. Often underdiagnosed as patients feel ashamed. Average delay to treatment in India is 7-10 years. Religious/cultural content in obsessions is common in India (fear of blasphemy, religious purity rituals). ERP therapists are scarce in India — NIMHANS and major centers provide training. SSRIs for OCD are affordable (generic fluoxetine Rs 2-3/day).

title: Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS)
chief_complaint: High fever, severe muscle rigidity, and altered consciousness after starting haloperidol
presentation: A 30-year-old man with schizophrenia was started on haloperidol 10mg IM for acute agitation 3 days ago at a psychiatric facility. He now develops high fever (40.5°C), generalized 'lead-pipe' muscle rigidity, altered consciousness, profuse sweating, and tachycardia. His CPK is markedly elevated. This is a life-threatening psychiatric emergency.
history: Known schizophrenia, recently admitted for acute psychotic episode. Started haloperidol 10mg IM (high-potency antipsychotic) 3 days ago. Day 1: Appeared stiff, attributed to EPS. Day 2: Developed fever 38.5°C, worsening rigidity. Day 3: High fever 40.5°C, severe rigidity, altered sensorium, diaphoretic, tachycardic. No prior NMS episodes. Also on trihexyphenidyl (anticholinergic). No recent dehydration. No recent restraint use.
physical_exam: Altered consciousness (GCS 10). Severe generalized 'lead-pipe' rigidity (constant resistance throughout range of motion — NOT cogwheel). Profuse diaphoresis. Hyperthermia 40.5°C. Tachycardia 130. Labile BP. Tremor. Dysphagia. Incontinence. No focal neurological signs. Deep tendon reflexes: Decreased (masked by rigidity).
investigations: CPK: 15,000 IU/L (markedly elevated — rhabdomyolysis; normal <200). WBC: 18,000 (leukocytosis). Creatinine: 2.5 (AKI from myoglobinuria). Urine: Dark brown (myoglobinuria). Myoglobin: Elevated. LFT: Mildly elevated transaminases. Electrolytes: Calcium low, Phosphate high. Coagulation: Mildly deranged. Iron levels: Low (often seen in NMS). CT brain: Normal. LP: Normal (rules out meningitis).
diagnosis: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) secondary to haloperidol — life-threatening antipsychotic complication
learning_points: NMS tetrad: Fever + Rigidity (lead-pipe) + Altered mental status + Autonomic instability
Most common with high-potency typical antipsychotics (haloperidol) but can occur with ANY antipsychotic
Risk factors: High dose, rapid dose escalation, IM route, dehydration, agitation, restraint use
STOP the offending drug immediately. Supportive: ICU, cooling, IV fluids, monitor CPK and renal function
Specific treatment: Dantrolene (muscle relaxant for rigidity) and/or Bromocriptine (dopamine agonist)
ECT is effective for treatment-resistant NMS and lethal catatonia
india_context: NMS is underrecognized in Indian psychiatric facilities. Haloperidol is still widely used (cheapest antipsychotic) despite higher NMS risk. Overcrowded wards, dehydration, and restraint use increase risk. Many psychiatric facilities lack ICU access. IPS recommends: Low starting dose, adequate hydration, avoid IM depot in first-episode patients, monitor temperature.

title: Anorexia Nervosa in a Teenager
chief_complaint: Extreme weight loss, refusal to eat, and excessive exercise
presentation: A 16-year-old girl from an affluent Mumbai family is brought by her parents with alarming weight loss (BMI 14.5, from 21 one year ago), refusal to eat adequate meals, self-induced vomiting after eating, and exercising excessively (running 10 km daily). She expresses intense fear of gaining weight and perceives herself as 'fat' despite being severely emaciated. She has developed amenorrhea.
history: Started 'dieting' 1 year ago after being called 'chubby' by a classmate. Progressive restriction of food intake. Currently eating ~400 kcal/day (should be ~2000). Self-induced vomiting after meals (purging). Excessive exercise: Runs 10 km daily, does not rest. Intense fear of weight gain (weighs herself 5-6 times daily). Body image distortion: Perceives herself as fat (BMI 14.5 — severely underweight). Amenorrhea for 6 months. Hair loss. Cold intolerance. Fatigue. Constipation. Social isolation. Academic performance maintained (perfectionistic personality). No substance use.
physical_exam: BMI 14.5 (severely underweight; <17.5 criteria met). Emaciated, sunken eyes, dry skin. Lanugo hair on face and arms (malnutrition). Bradycardia (48/min). Hypotension (85/55). Hypothermia (35.8°C). Parotid enlargement (purging). Russell's sign: Calluses on knuckles (self-induced vomiting). Dental erosion (enamel loss from gastric acid). Pedal edema (hypoalbuminemia). Muscle wasting. Hair thinning.
investigations: BMI: 14.5 (severe anorexia <15). ECG: Sinus bradycardia, prolonged QTc (risk of arrhythmia — most dangerous complication). Electrolytes: K+ 2.8 (hypokalemia from purging), Na+ 132. Glucose: 55 (hypoglycemia). Albumin: 2.5. CBC: Hb 10.0, WBC 3,000 (leucopenia), platelets normal. LFT: Mildly elevated. TFT: Low T3 (sick euthyroid syndrome — adaptive). Cortisol: Elevated (stress response). Estradiol: Low (amenorrhea). DEXA: Osteopenia (low estrogen). Amylase: Elevated (parotid — purging marker).
diagnosis: Anorexia nervosa — restricting and binge-purge subtype, severe (BMI 14.5) with medical complications
differentials: Major depressive disorder with appetite loss
learning_points: Anorexia nervosa criteria: Restriction of intake → low body weight + Intense fear of gaining weight + Body image distortion
Medical emergencies: Bradycardia, prolonged QTc, severe hypokalemia, hypoglycemia — cardiac arrest is leading cause of death
Refeeding syndrome: Starting nutrition too aggressively causes fatal hypophosphatemia — start LOW and GO SLOW (10-15 kcal/kg/day)
Treatment: Nutritional rehabilitation + Family-based therapy (FBT/Maudsley approach) for adolescents + SSRI if comorbid depression/OCD
No medication is FDA-approved for anorexia nervosa — treatment is primarily psychological and nutritional
Anorexia has the HIGHEST mortality of any psychiatric disorder (5-10% mortality rate)
india_context: Eating disorders are increasingly recognized in urban India, especially among affluent adolescent girls. Previously considered Western, now reported from metro cities. Cultural factors: Body image pressure from media, competitive academic environment. NIMHANS Bengaluru and AIIMS Delhi have specialized eating disorder clinics. Most Indian psychiatrists receive limited training in eating disorders. Early identification by pediatricians and school counselors is critical.

title: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) After a Severe Road Traffic Accident
source: IPS Guidelines - Trauma and Stressor-Related Disorders
chief_complaint: Recurrent nightmares of a road accident, severe anxiety while driving, and disturbed sleep for 4 months
presentation: A 34-year-old male sales executive from Pune presents with persistent distressing symptoms for 4 months following a severe road traffic accident on the Mumbai-Pune Expressway. He was driving when a truck collided head-on with a car in the adjacent lane, causing a multi-vehicle pile-up. His car spun off the road and overturned. He sustained rib fractures and a concussion but survived. His colleague in the passenger seat died at the scene. Since the accident, he has vivid recurring nightmares of the collision 3-4 times per week, waking up screaming and drenched in sweat. He avoids driving or even sitting in a car, has taken a leave of absence from work (which requires extensive travel), and becomes extremely anxious and has palpitations when he hears sudden loud noises (horns, braking sounds). He feels emotionally numb, has detached from his wife and children, and reports persistent guilt about surviving when his colleague died.
history: Road traffic accident 4 months ago: Multi-vehicle collision on expressway, car overturned, passenger (close colleague) died on scene. Patient sustained 2 rib fractures and mild concussion, hospitalized for 5 days. Physical injuries have healed. Psychiatric symptoms began within 1 week of the accident and have persisted beyond 1 month (meets PTSD duration criterion). Re-experiencing: Vivid nightmares of the accident 3-4 times/week, intrusive flashbacks triggered by traffic sounds or news of road accidents, intense physiological distress (palpitations, sweating, trembling) when exposed to reminders. Avoidance: Refuses to drive or ride in cars, avoids the expressway and roads near the accident site, avoids news about road accidents, stopped socializing with colleagues (reminders of the deceased). Negative alterations in cognition and mood: Persistent survivor's guilt ('Why did I survive and he didn't?'), emotional numbing, detachment from family, loss of interest in previously enjoyed activities (cricket, movies), persistent negative beliefs ('The world is dangerous, nowhere is safe'), inability to recall specific details of the moment of impact (dissociative amnesia). Hyperarousal: Insomnia (sleeps only 3-4 hours due to fear of nightmares), hypervigilance (constantly scanning for danger), exaggerated startle response (jumps at loud sounds), irritability (frequent anger outbursts at family). No substance use as coping mechanism. No prior psychiatric history. No prior trauma exposure.
physical_exam: Appears anxious, tense, hypervigilant — eyes scanning the room. Startle response observed when door closed suddenly. Affect: Restricted, anxious, congruent with reported distress. Speech: Normal rate and volume. Mood: 'I feel like I'm stuck in that moment.' Thought content: Intrusive trauma-related imagery, survivor's guilt, no active suicidal ideation but reports passive death wishes ('It would have been easier if I hadn't survived'). No hallucinations. No delusions. Insight: Present — recognizes symptoms are related to the accident. Judgment: Partially impaired (avoidance behavior is maladaptive). Cognition: Intact but reports subjective difficulty concentrating at work. Physical: Healed rib fracture site, no tenderness. Neurological: No focal deficits.
investigations: PCL-5 (PTSD Checklist for DSM-5): Score 62/80 (severe PTSD; cutoff ≥33 suggests probable PTSD). PHQ-9: 14 (moderate comorbid depression). GAD-7: 16 (severe anxiety). AUDIT: 2 (no alcohol misuse). Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale: Passive suicidal ideation, no plan or intent (moderate risk — requires monitoring). TSH: Normal. CBC, LFT, RFT: Normal. CT brain (done at time of admission for concussion): No intracranial hemorrhage, resolved.
diagnosis: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) — DSM-5 criteria met (>1 month duration, all 4 symptom clusters present: intrusion, avoidance, negative alterations in cognition/mood, hyperarousal) with comorbid moderate depression, following a life-threatening road traffic accident
differentials: Acute stress disorder (if <1 month — this patient is at 4 months)
Adjustment disorder (less severe, does not meet full PTSD criteria)
Major depressive disorder (overlap but trauma-specific re-experiencing distinguishes PTSD)
Complicated grief / prolonged grief disorder (grief for deceased colleague is a component but full PTSD criteria are met)
learning_points: DSM-5 PTSD requires: (A) Exposure to actual/threatened death or serious injury, (B) Intrusion symptoms (flashbacks, nightmares, distress at reminders), (C) Avoidance of trauma-related stimuli, (D) Negative alterations in cognitions/mood, (E) Hyperarousal — symptoms must last >1 month and cause significant functional impairment

PTSD is distinct from acute stress disorder (ASD) which has similar symptoms but duration is 3 days to 1 month after trauma; not all ASD progresses to PTSD, but early intervention can prevent chronicity

Trauma-focused psychotherapies are first-line: Prolonged Exposure (PE) therapy and Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT) have the strongest evidence; EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing) is also effective and increasingly available

Pharmacotherapy for PTSD: SSRIs (sertraline 50-200 mg or paroxetine 20-50 mg) are first-line medications; prazosin (1-15 mg at bedtime) is specifically effective for trauma-related nightmares by blocking noradrenergic hyperactivation

Survivor's guilt is a common feature of PTSD when others died in the same traumatic event — it contributes to depression, suicidal ideation, and functional impairment and must be specifically addressed in therapy
Comorbidities are the rule in PTSD: 50-80% have comorbid depression, 30-50% have substance use disorders, and suicidal ideation is present in 30% — comprehensive assessment is mandatory
india_context: Road traffic accidents are the leading cause of trauma-related PTSD in India, with approximately 1.5 lakh road deaths annually (MoRTH data 2022). PTSD following RTAs is significantly underdiagnosed as mental health sequelae are rarely assessed during post-accident medical follow-up. The concept of psychological trauma is poorly understood by the general public in India, and symptoms are often attributed to 'weakness' or dismissed as 'nervousness.' Trained trauma-focused psychotherapists (CBT/PE/EMDR) are scarce in India and concentrated in metropolitan cities. NIMHANS Bengaluru, AIIMS Delhi, and LGBRIMH Tezpur have specialized trauma clinics. The Mental Healthcare Act 2017 provides a framework for mental health services but implementation gaps remain. Generic sertraline (Rs 3-5/day) is affordable but access to prazosin for nightmares and structured psychotherapy remains limited outside major centers. The DMHP (District Mental Health Programme) is gradually incorporating trauma care into its framework.

title: Cannabis-Induced Psychosis in a College Student with Emerging Substance Use Disorder
source: IPS Guidelines - Substance Use Disorders and Cannabis-Related Psychosis
chief_complaint: Bizarre behavior, paranoia, and aggression after consuming cannabis (bhang/ganja) for 2 days
presentation: A 20-year-old male undergraduate student from Varanasi is brought to the emergency department by his hostel warden and two friends with a 2-day history of bizarre behavior, paranoid ideation, and aggression that began after heavy cannabis use during a college festival. He had consumed large quantities of bhang (cannabis-infused drink) over 2 consecutive days and also smoked ganja (marijuana) multiple times. On the evening of the second day, he became agitated, started accusing his roommate of being a spy, barricaded himself in his room, and was found talking rapidly and incoherently. He attempted to assault a friend who tried to calm him down. His friends report that he has been using cannabis regularly (2-3 times/week) for the past 18 months and has been using increasing amounts. His academic performance has declined significantly, and he has dropped two courses this semester.
history: Cannabis use began 18 months ago during first year of college, initially occasional (weekends, social settings). Gradually increased to 2-3 times/week over the past 6 months. Smokes ganja joints and also consumes bhang during festivals and social gatherings. Tolerance: Needs increasing amounts to achieve desired effect. Craving: Strong urge to use, especially in the evenings. Withdrawal: Reports irritability, poor appetite, and insomnia when he tries to stop (has attempted twice). Current episode: Heavy cannabis use over 2 consecutive days during college festival — consumed 3-4 large glasses of concentrated bhang plus smoked 4-5 joints of ganja over 48 hours. Symptoms began within hours of last heavy use: became suspicious, restless, started speaking rapidly. Developed paranoid delusions that his roommate was a government spy recording his conversations. Barricaded himself in his room. Attempted physical aggression. No prior psychiatric history before cannabis use. No family history of psychosis (important to assess). Academic decline: GPA dropped from 7.8 to 5.2, dropped 2 courses, attendance issues. Social changes: Shifted peer group to cannabis-using friends, conflict with parents over behavior changes. No alcohol use. No other substance use (no opioids, stimulants, or inhalants). No head injury.
physical_exam: Agitated, uncooperative, requires physical restraint by two attendants. Conjunctival injection (red eyes — cannabis effect). Appears disheveled, strong smell of cannabis on clothing. Tachycardic, mildly hypertensive. Speech: Pressured, loud, tangential. Affect: Labile — alternates between anger and fearfulness. Thought content: Paranoid delusions (roommate is a spy, hostel is under surveillance), ideas of reference (news on TV is about him). Perceptual disturbance: Reports hearing whispering voices that others cannot hear (auditory hallucinations). Insight: Absent. Judgment: Severely impaired. Orientation: Disoriented to time, oriented to place and person. No focal neurological deficits. No signs of other substance use (no injection marks, no nasal septal perforation, no features of opioid or stimulant use).
investigations: Urine drug screen (immunoassay): Positive for cannabinoids (THC metabolites). Negative for opioids, amphetamines, benzodiazepines, cocaine, and phencyclidine. Blood THC level: Not routinely available. CBC: Hb 13.5, WBC 9,200, Platelets 2.8 lakh — normal. RBS: 102 mg/dL. LFT, RFT: Normal. TFT: Normal (rules out thyrotoxicosis). HIV: Non-reactive. CT brain: Normal (rules out organic cause). EEG: Normal (no epileptiform activity). CUDIT-R (Cannabis Use Disorder Identification Test — Revised): 22/32 (score >8 suggests cannabis use disorder). BPRS (Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale): 56 (severe psychotic symptoms).
diagnosis: Cannabis-induced psychotic disorder with delusions and hallucinations (DSM-5: substance/medication-induced psychotic disorder) in the context of moderate-to-severe cannabis use disorder
differentials: First-episode schizophrenia (must follow up — cannabis psychosis can unmask latent schizophrenia)
Bipolar disorder — manic episode with psychosis
Stimulant-induced psychosis (ruled out by drug screen)
Delirium (partially oriented, no clouding of consciousness — less likely)
learning_points: Cannabis-induced psychosis typically presents within hours to days of heavy cannabis use with paranoid delusions, hallucinations (auditory > visual), agitation, and disorganized behavior; it usually resolves within days to weeks of abstinence, distinguishing it from primary psychotic disorders

DSM-5 criteria for substance-induced psychotic disorder: (1) prominent delusions/hallucinations, (2) symptoms developed during or soon after substance intoxication/withdrawal, (3) the substance is capable of producing psychosis, (4) not better explained by an independent psychotic disorder — key distinguishing factors from primary psychosis include onset in close temporal relation to heavy use and resolution with abstinence

Cannabis use disorder (CUD) is diagnosed when a pattern of use leads to clinically significant impairment with ≥2 of 11 criteria in 12 months (tolerance, withdrawal, craving, larger amounts, failed attempts to cut down, time spent, social/occupational impairment, hazardous use, continued despite problems, activities given up)

THC (delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol) acts on CB1 receptors in the mesolimbic dopamine pathway, increasing dopamine release — this is the mechanism underlying cannabis-induced psychosis; higher THC potency products carry greater psychosis risk

Approximately 10-15% of patients with cannabis-induced psychosis go on to develop schizophrenia within 3-5 years — longitudinal follow-up is essential, especially in patients with a family history of psychotic disorders; early cannabis use (<16 years) increases schizophrenia risk 4-6 fold

Management of acute cannabis psychosis: Low-dose antipsychotic (haloperidol 2-5 mg or olanzapine 5-10 mg) for symptom control, benzodiazepine for agitation (lorazepam 2 mg), supportive environment; antipsychotics can usually be tapered and stopped within 2-4 weeks if symptoms resolve with abstinence
india_context: Cannabis is the most commonly used illicit substance in India, with an estimated 3.1 crore (31 million) users per the AIIMS-NDDTC National Survey on Extent and Patterns of Substance Use in India (2019). Bhang (cannabis-infused drink) is legally sold in many Indian states during festivals like Holi, Maha Shivaratri, and other occasions, and its use is culturally normalized in North India, particularly in Varanasi, Mathura, and Rajasthan. This cultural acceptance makes it harder for young people to recognize problematic use patterns. College campuses are a high-risk environment for cannabis initiation and escalation. The NDPS Act (Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, 1985) criminalizes cannabis possession and sale (except bhang in some states), but enforcement is inconsistent. NIMHANS Bengaluru and NDDTC-AIIMS Delhi are leading centers for addiction research and treatment. The Indian Psychiatric Society recommends screening for cannabis use in all young patients presenting with first-episode psychosis. Access to structured de-addiction programs and psychosocial interventions (motivational enhancement therapy, contingency management) remains limited in most Indian cities.
